Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Developing periodic life cycles through interspecies competition
Award.AbstractNarration:
Population cycles occur in many plants and animals; however the causes of these cycles are usually unknown. For example, although there are 13- and 17-year cicadas in the United States which exhibit periodic outbreaks in their populations every 13 or 17 years, cicadas in Japan are prevalent every summer and lack such periodicity. The understanding of population cycles is important to managing fisheries and crops, protecting endangered species, and dealing with species invasions and the spread of epidemics. In this research, the causes of periodic life cycles will be investigated through a model of two competing populations. When isolated, the populations do not exhibit periodic outbreaks; however, when together, the interactions between them cause both to develop periodic outbreaks similar to those of the famous 13- and 17-year cicadas found in the eastern United States. This research will be done at the University of Miyazaki in Japan with Professor Ryusuke Kon, a leading researcher of periodicity in population dynamics.

The equilibria and cycles of the discrete-time matrix model and their stabilities will be determined, first through numerical exploration and then analytically. A bifurcation analysis of the system will also be done to determine dynamics' dependence on the model parameters. In addition to a basic linear stability analysis, some specific methods of analysis may include using Lyapunov functions, the Lyapunov-Schmidt reduction, and/or center-manifold theory. The dynamics of the model, particularly the stable equilibria which correspond to phenomena likely to be found in nature, will then be related to existing organisms. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Population cycles occur in many plants and animals, though the causes of these cycles is usually unknown. A common example are the 13- and 17-year cicadas in the United States; contrasting these cicadas are those in Japan which lack such periodicity. The understanding of population cycles is important to managing fisheries and crops, protecting endangered species, and dealing with species invasions and the spread of epidemics.

 

To determine potential causes of periodic life cycles, a simple four-dimensional system of differential equations was proposed to observe the dynamics of two competing species, each with two life stages. When isolated, the populations do not exhibit periodic outbreaks; however, when together, the interactions between them can cause both to develop periodic outbreaks. The dynamics of the model depends on the competition parameter values. The goal of the project was to locate and analyze the equilibria of the model, based on variable parameter values. In order to visualize simulations of the four-dimensional system, a Mathematica script was written to show the trajectory of the simulation in a tetrahedron as well as to plot the equilibria and their stability via numerical computation.

 

The possible equilibria of the model were located analytically. The equilibria were said to exist if they were non-negative, corresponding to non-negative population sizes. The existence of most of the equilibria was determined, with some equilibria existing in every scenario and others only existing in specific situations but coexisting with other equilibria. The stability of the equilibria were also studied, both mathematically and numerically. For some of the equilibria, stability or instability was proven, and for others there were numerical simulations showing examples of stability and instability. A conjecture was also made that certain events of existence and stability were disjoint, as observed in the numerical simulations.

 

In addition to the opportunity to collaborate on this project, the fellowship also allowed the PI to attend related seminars and conferences, which will also assist with future research projects. It also provided an opportunity to network with international collaborators and provided a mentoring experience for the professor who does not have any current graduate students. The PI also presented and discussed the results at the university in Japan to the mathematics professors.
